to Ofsted will mean schools will be judged by the watchdog on four key areas- quality of teaching, leadership, pupils' behaviour and achievement. Publishing the Bill on Thursday, Mr Michael Gove said: There are areas of Ofsted inspections, such as community cohesion or regulations Michael Governing what students bring in in their lunchboxes at lunchtime, which are entirely peripheral. "One of the problems with Ofsted inspections is that they are asked to inspect and measure for things which, by definition, are hard to judge and not central to what schools are about. The Bill hands more control to the Education Secretary to intervene in failing schools. Mr Michael Gove insisted that under-achieving academies will not be exempt from this. , including the former BBC director-general Greg Dyke , have expressed fears that the verdict will stop broadcasting executives from doing their jobs properly. However, speaking on BBC One's Question Time, Mr Michael Gove said: Sometimes it's good that things are new and fresh, like technology or fashion or music. Sometimes you want things to be old, like cheese, wine or the presenter of Question Time. I hope that everyone at the BBC gets the message. I would rather see Selina Scott and Joanna Lumley on my TV screens than Holly Willoughby and Fearne Cotton . Selina Scott , now 59, settled an age discrimination case against Channel 5 two years ago for a reported? 250,000. Holly Willoughby , 29, presents ITV's Dancing on Ice with Phillip Schofield . warns that Michael Gove 's plans for a narrow 1950s-style curriculum could lead to young people switching off from learning, playing up in the classroom and finding themselves unprepared for the modern workplace," he said.
